channel.title: Im confused with java
channel.description:
im stuck and confused with somthing in this tutorial
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/java/TOC.html
this is from java.sun.com and its the first section i just dont under stand it cn someon give m a run through? please id really appreciate it thanks ^>^

item.title: Im confused with java
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“lesterknome, post:5, topic:308462”][quote author=Uriko link=topic=404910.msg2994662#msg2994662 date=1255491911]
Maybe java’s not for you. You’re only 13, maybe you can’t grasp the concepts of the programming language yet, maybe try something else… like VB.
[/quote]

I started Java when i was 10 and im 12 atm, you are never too young.
[center] Too young to be on these forums. Banned for a year until you are 13.[/center][/quote]

lol’ed harder than ever

if you wanna learn some java try http://sean.cruels.net/ its where i learned from. [size=1pt]bring on the flame[/size]

C# and C++ are, at least I think they are. Anyways, it’s obvious he is lying.[/quote]uhh no they arent

item.title: Im confused with java
item.dc:creator: @cows_be_sacred cows_be_sacred
item.description:
@cows_be_sacred wrote:

What part of the first section?

An object is a software bundle of related state and behavior. Software objects are often used to model the real-world objects that you find in everyday life. This lesson explains how state and behavior are represented within an object, introduces the concept of data encapsulation, and explains the benefits of designing your software in this manner.
A class is a blueprint or prototype from which objects are created. This section defines a class that models the state and behavior of a real-world object. It intentionally focuses on the basics, showing how even a simple class can cleanly model state and behavior.
Inheritance provides a powerful and natural mechanism for organizing and structuring your software. This section explains how classes inherit state and behavior from their superclasses, and explains how to derive one class from another using the simple syntax provided by the Java programming language.
An interface is a contract between a class and the outside world. When a class implements an interface, it promises to provide the behavior published by that interface. This section defines a simple interface and explains the necessary changes for any class that implements it.
A package is a namespace for organizing classes and interfaces in a logical manner. Placing your code into packages makes large software projects easier to manage. This section explains why this is useful, and introduces you to the Application Programming Interface (API) provided by the Java platform.

Read full topic
